head.title: The Candidate's Muse: Books or Life?

hedline.hl1: The Candidate's Muse: Books or Life?

abstract.p: Jesse Feiler letter on June 25 article deplores anti-intellectualism that he sees going beyond presidential race; drawing

block.p: You discuss anti-intellectualism and the preference for pragmatism and sound decision-making as they affect presidential candidates (''What a Mind! In Politics, That's Not What Matters,'' Week in Review, June 25).

You discuss anti-intellectualism and the preference for pragmatism and sound decision-making as they affect presidential candidates (''What a Mind! In Politics, That's Not What Matters,'' Week in Review, June 25).

These traits are ingrained in the national character and extend far beyond presidential elections. Pragmatism and self-reliance are preferred to ''book learning'' -- perhaps as a vestige of traits needed to settle a hostile wilderness. Further complicating the picture is that the country was founded by people who refused to bend the knee in obeisance to anyone, and as a result of that abhorrence of deference and servitude, the concept of any kind of personal service is looked on dimly.

The new global economy based on the Internet and technology appears to be a service-centered economy in which ideas (abstract concepts or popular ''content'') matter. Until the United States and its leaders promote the value of intellectual (impractical) pursuits and the worth of personal service, the country's future is in doubt.
